conclusion: For an empty (air-filled) coaxial capacitor of height l, inner radius a and outer radius b that is held at a fixed potential difference V, the stored electrostatic energy is calculated using the formula U = ½ C V².

premise: The capacitance per unit length is C = 2π ε₀ l / ln(b/a).
conclusion: The stored electrostatic energy is U(l) = ½ [ 2π ε₀ l / ln(b/a) ] V².

premise: The stored electrostatic energy is U(l) = ½ [ 2π ε₀ l / ln(b/a) ] V².
conclusion: The stored electrostatic energy is U(l) = (π ε₀ V² l) / ln(b/a).
This expression is linear in the height l because, before any fluid rises, every centimetre of the capacitor length contributes the same amount of capacitance.

premise: The stored electrostatic energy is U(l) = (π ε₀ V² l) / ln(b/a).
conclusion: The total energy stored in the capacitor before any fluid rises is U = (π ε₀ V² l) / ln(b/a).
